content: David Strugach
notes.title: Patient Name

content: Bilateral hand contractures
notes.title: Chief Complaint

content: right-hand dominant retiree

He presents today for evaluation of contracture of his bilateral hands that began many years ago.  He states that he first noticed this on his left hand many years ago and now he is starting to notice it on his right hand.  He notes that the left hand is unable to get flat on the table.  He has significant contracture of the ring finger.  He is here today for evaluation and treatment.

data: He reports the onset of bilateral hand contractures several years ago, initially affecting his left hand. He is now experiencing contractures in his right hand as well. The left hand cannot lie flat on a table, with significant contracture of the little finger.  He seeks evaluation and treatment for these contractures.
to: He presents today for evaluation of contracture of his bilateral hands that began many years ago.  He states that he first noticed this on his left hand many years ago and now he is starting to notice it on his right hand.  He notes that the left hand is unable to get flat on the table.  He has significant contracture of the ring finger.  He is here today for evaluation and treatment.

notes.title: History of Present Illness

content: Left upper extremity
Skin is clean, dry and intact without erythema or ecchymosis
There is significant cord formation and nodules along the ring finger ray consistent with Dupuytren’s disease
There is a 45-degree contracture at the ring finger metacarpophalangeal joint
There is about a 10-degree contracture at the ring finger proximal interphalangeal joint
No measurable contracture at any remaining digits
Right upper extremity
Skin is clean, dry and intact
There are nodules and cords along the ring finger ray consistent with Dupuytren’s disease
Able to get hands flat on the table
There is no evidence of contracture of the hand
